bibl.title: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Philip Showalter Hench, July 17, 1941

div1.p: Ireland thanks Hench for the photographs and copy of his speech. He feels Kissinger should be sent to a Veterans Bureau Hospital, not to Walter Reed Hospital. He refers Hench to a friend, in Washington, who has a suggestion about locating Camp Lazear. He informs Hench that Blossom Reed has recovered well from her illness.

div1.head: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Philip Showalter Hench, July 17, 1941
div1.opener:
Y F.
1870 Wyoming Avenue,
Washington, D.C.,
July 17, 1941
Doctor Philip S. Hench,
The Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your letter of July 10th
inclosing photographs you took when we were down at Washing-
ton Barracks and a copy of your address at the unveiling cere-
monies at Cleveland. It was very nice of you to send me the
photographs and the copy of your address which I have read
again with a great deal of interest. I missed in your address
the preliminary remarks you made with reference to your con-
tact with the Wythe people when you were a youngster. Those re-
marks appealed to me very much.

Your letter to George Carroll was an extremely nice
one and I am very glad you wrote him. My guess is that you will
not receive a reply from him. I intended to take your address
down to him and give it to him and tell him personally of the un-
veiling ceremony at Cleveland. I am not sure that we are going to
get any response from him but I think we should be nice to him and
give him all the information we have.

I am sorry about Kissinger, sorry that he had his cere-
bral accident and sorry that he is hanging on. If he is to be hos-
pitalized he should be sent to the Veterans Bureau hospital at In-
dianapolis or some place in that vicinity. Walter Reed is not the
place for him. They can only keep patients for a certain length
of time at Walter Reed and I don't think that they take these
chronic cases. If they had any other policy, in a very short time
Walter Reed would not be an active hospital but would be a home for
people chronically ill.

Mrs. Ireland and I enjoyed our meetings in Cleveland
very much but I did not get an opportunity to tell you one thing.
I have a newspaper friend here, David Rankin Barbee, who is quite
a research man and who knows as much about the yellow fever inves-
tigations as any newspaper man. When I told him the story of your
trips to Havana and the purchase of the cabin down there and your
determination to have it placed where it would be cared for in the
future, he remarked that the Walter Reed reservation here in the
District is the only place for it. I am giving you this statement
for what it is worth from a newspaper man who is a great friend of
medical people.

Yes, Blossom Reed has been ill and it was the intention to
transfer her to Walter Reed hospital but the news comes now that she
-2-
is very, very much better and I hope will be on her feet before
very long. My understanding is that the so-called heart at-
tack was not serious.

Don't fail to let us know when you expect to make your
trip this way in the Fall.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, M. W. Ireland Gen Keans son is taking
his vacation just now, and
Saturday will come for Gen Mrs
Kean and take them to his house
in Richmond for a week. You
can imagine how happy he will
be down there with his son and
two grandchildren. We gave
Kean a fine 81 “birthday party
June 27”
